values.title: Bug in URDF to SDF converter (with physical properties)

content.raw:
URDF-to-SDF convertor doesn't export physical parameters if collision tag in link has name-attribute which is not begining with parent link's name-attribute.

Conversion command was used:
```
#!c++
gz sdf --verbose -p model.urdf > model.sdf
```


This example doesn't export gazebo physical properties (mu1, mu2):

```
#!xml

  <gazebo reference="link2">
    <mu1>0.2</mu1>
    <mu2>0.2</mu2>
  </gazebo>

  <link name="link2">
    <collision name="test_collision">
     ...
```

Next examples are fine:
- collision without name specified
```
#!xml

  <gazebo reference="link2">
    <mu1>0.2</mu1>
    <mu2>0.2</mu2>
  </gazebo>

  <link name="link2">
    <collision>
     ...
```

- collision's name beginning with link's name
```
#!xml

  <gazebo reference="link2">
    <mu1>0.2</mu1>
    <mu2>0.2</mu2>
  </gazebo>

  <link name="link2">
    <collision name="link2_collision">
     ...
```

values.title: Laser Scan Bug with Wobbling Model

content.raw: I was working on writing navigation nodes using laser sensors when I started seeing strange anomalies in the data being received, which was causing my nodes to not function properly. Chunks of the scan data appeared to be missing, but there isn't actually any data missing, it's just not accurate. After testing I realized it had to do with the roll and pitch of the robot. If the robot clipped an object or ran into something this issue would occur, and I confirmed by having the robot drive over an uneven surface to throw it off balance and the laser would immediately start bugging out. Screenshots attached.
content.html: I was working on writing navigation nodes using laser sensors when I started seeing strange anomalies in the data being received, which was causing my nodes to not function properly. Chunks of the scan data appeared to be missing, but there isn't actually any data missing, it's just not accurate. After testing I realized it had to do with the roll and pitch of the robot. If the robot clipped an object or ran into something this issue would occur, and I confirmed by having the robot drive over an uneven surface to throw it off balance and the laser would immediately start bugging out. Screenshots attached.

values.title: Multiple ROS GPU laser plugins interfere

content.raw:
I observed a strange behaviour today when testing the GPU ray sensor with a robot with multiple laser sensors: Using two different GPU laser plugins seem to cause a warped point cloud output when only one is subscribed. Although it seems to be a problem specific to the plugins used I think it could be a bug in the GpuRaySensor class. Below I provide a sample setup to reproduce it.

![warped_gpu_laser.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1946734069-warped_gpu_laser.png)

I used the *libgazebo_ros_gpu_laser* plugin ([gazebo_plugins](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs)) for a Sick 2D LiDAR sensor publishing on `/sick_points` and the *libgazebo_ros_velodyne_gpu_laser* ([velodyne_gazebo_plugins](https://bitbucket.org/DataspeedInc/velodyne_simulator/src/master/)) plugin for a Velodyne 3D LiDAR sensor publishing on `/velodyne_points` (see also attached SDF) on the same robot.

**To reproduce this behaviour:**

1. Use the robot defined in the attached SDF, insert it in Gazebo
2. Display the output of the 2D LiDAR on topic `/sick_points`, e.g. with RVIZ. You should see a warped/faulty LaserScan (left side of the picture above)
3. Only now subscribe to the other 3D LiDAR on topic `/velodyne_points`, e.g. by `rostopic echo /velodyne_points` or also via RVIZ. You should see that suddenly the 2D LaserScan is correct! (right side of the picture above).

Both plugins seem to work correctly when used separately. Also this bug does not appear when laser visualization in Gazebo is turned on.

The problem could as well be in one of the plugins but because I think the only way they could possibly interact is via the GpuRaySensor I guess it's a problem with the GpuRaySensor component.Probably subscribing to the second sensor output triggers something that fixes the output of the first sensor.

Does anyone have an idea what the problem might be?

Gazebo version is 7.14.0
content.html:
I observed a strange behaviour today when testing the GPU ray sensor with a robot with multiple laser sensors: Using two different GPU laser plugins seem to cause a warped point cloud output when only one is subscribed. Although it seems to be a problem specific to the plugins used I think it could be a bug in the GpuRaySensor class. Below I provide a sample setup to reproduce it.

I used the libgazebo_ros_gpu_laser plugin (gazebo_plugins) for a Sick 2D LiDAR sensor publishing on /sick_points and the libgazebo_ros_velodyne_gpu_laser (velodyne_gazebo_plugins) plugin for a Velodyne 3D LiDAR sensor publishing on /velodyne_points (see also attached SDF) on the same robot.

To reproduce this behaviour:

  1. Use the robot defined in the attached SDF, insert it in Gazebo
  2. Display the output of the 2D LiDAR on topic /sick_points, e.g. with RVIZ. You should see a warped/faulty LaserScan (left side of the picture above)
  3. Only now subscribe to the other 3D LiDAR on topic /velodyne_points, e.g. by rostopic echo /velodyne_points or also via RVIZ. You should see that suddenly the 2D LaserScan is correct! (right side of the picture above).

Both plugins seem to work correctly when used separately. Also this bug does not appear when laser visualization in Gazebo is turned on.

The problem could as well be in one of the plugins but because I think the only way they could possibly interact is via the GpuRaySensor I guess it's a problem with the GpuRaySensor component.Probably subscribing to the second sensor output triggers something that fixes the output of the first sensor.

Does anyone have an idea what the problem might be?

Gazebo version is 7.14.0

values.title: [Gazebo9] Video Plugin Crashes Gzserver

content.raw:
Hello all,

It seems that the video plugin `libgazebo_ros_video.so` is crashing gzserver everytime I load it in ROS Kinetic + Gazebo 9. 

This is the code snippet:
``` <gazebo reference="screen">

    <visual>

      <plugin name="screen_video_controller" filename="libgazebo_ros_video.so">

        <height>600</height>

        <width>1024</width>

        <topicName>/robot/head_display</topicName>

        <robotNamespace>/robot</robotNamespace>

      </plugin>

    </visual>

  </gazebo>
```

If I try to load this model, I'll get:
```[ INFO] [1533119655.853751756]: GazeboRosVideo (gzclient, ns = /robot) has started

Segmentation fault (core dumped)

[gazebo_gui-3] process has died [pid 12932, exit code 139, cmd /opt/ros/kinetic/lib/gazebo_ros/gzclient __name:=gazebo_gui __log:=/home/arif/.ros/log/6157ef48-9576-11e8-90e1-6c71d97cbaff/gazebo_gui-3.log].
log file: /home/arif/.ros/log/6157ef48-9576-11e8-90e1-6c71d97cbaff/gazebo_gui-3*.log
```

But if I comment out that part, it loads ok (without that video display, of course). 

I understand that in Gazebo 7 it was outputting a warning #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2202/gazebo7-visualplugins-are-deprecated , but in my Gazebo 9 it just crashes. 

Can anyone help?
